passages.text: August 29, 2025 11:23 AM GMT

Markets continue to expect a 5% chance of an October rate hike and 1.7 25bp hikes over the next 12 months. However, incoming data from the US and Japan appear to be slowing due to US tariff policy. We see the risk/reward for duration as skewed towards the bullish side and expect the belly of the curve to outperform.

In the absence of other major themes, market participants continue to focus on BoJ rate hike prospects and super- long JGB supply/demand. BoJ board member Nakagawa didn't hint at anything regarding the next rate hike, but she mentioned that the next Tanakan will be important. Hence, the market continues to price in roughly a \(50\%\) chance of an October hike. That said, Japan's production/export and US labor market data, which BoJ Governor Ueda mentioned in July's MPM to assess the impact of US tariff policy, have started to show some weakness. Further deterioration in those numbers may cause markets to start pricing in a dovish pivot by the BoJ. Speculation about the MoF's further issuance reduction supported long- end JGBs this week, but we think it would not be enough to stabilize supply/demand in the long end. As such, we maintain long 10y JGB, JGB 10s30s steepener and short 30y JGB ASW. We think that current long- end JGB buyers would flip to sellers on any strength.
Please add me to your distribution list.
MORGAN STANLEY MUFG SECURITIES CO., LTD. +

In the absence of other major themes, market participants currently continue to focus on BoJ rate hike prospects and super- long JGB supply/demand. Little has changed with regard to the former over the past week or so, with the market- implied probability of an October hike remaining at around \(52\%\) .

Markets appear to have been hoping that BoJ policy board member Junko Nakagawa would offer an update on how the central bank perceives the US economic outlook in her August 28 speech at a meeting with local leaders in Yamaguchi, with Governor Kazuo Ueda having (four weeks earlier) cited the risk of tariff policy causing growth to slow in his July post- meeting press conference.

Nakagawa did not end up directly addressing that topic, although her prepared text did cite trade policies as a major contributing factor for two of the three "risks to economic activity and prices" that she listed.

Our economists found the overall wording to be a little on the cautious side, and she also indicated in her follow- up press conference that uncertainties continue to warrant attention despite having diminished to some degree by comparison with April (at least with regard to trade policy), with the BoJ accordingly intending to keep a close eye on the tariff impact as seen in the September Tankan results and other incoming data.

Nakagawa meanwhile appeared satisfied that overall inflation trends remain intact. While the BoJ's "underlying inflation" measures such as the trimmed mean and weighted median CPI inflation rates slowed down recently, she noted that the distribution of inflation rates for CPI components remains bunched around \(+2\%\) , with inflation expectations also closing in on that level.
Such communications will likely have left market participants concluding that an October hike cannot yet be ruled out if the October 1 Tankan release proves sufficiently encouraging.
That said, the Tokyo CPI release for August has finally offered some signs of upward pressure on goods prices (particularly via the rice price channel) starting to ease (see Exhibit 1).

Furthermore, there are signs of sluggishness in general service inflation and other goods inflation as well (see Exhibit 2). If food price inflation starts to decelerate as our economists expect, markets are likely to dial back their rate hike expectations, in our view.
Exhibit 1: Tokyo CPI rice, food product outside the home inflation
Source: Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications, Morgan Stanley Research
Exhibit 2: Tokyo CPI goods inflation ex food and energy products and general service inflation YoY

Source: Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications, Morgan Stanley Research; Note: Volatile factors includes internet and mobile charges, charge for package tours, hotel charges. The chart removes the effect of free high school fees starting from April 24.

Our economists also expect exports, domestic production and US employment trends to weigh quite heavily on the BoJ's rate hike thinking given that Governor Ueda indicated in his July press conference that the central bank will be looking at hard data on such variables as it attempts to gauge the tariff policy impact.

As our economists discussed in Sharp Decline in Real Exports in July: Tariff Impact Likely to Become More Pronounced, August 20, 2025, Japanese real exports have clearly begun to slow, with Japan industrial production for July also decreasing (see Exhibit 3).

Leading indicators for the US labor market have also been showing further signs of weakness ahead of the September 5 Employment Situation release (see Exhibit 4). Another deterioration in those numbers may very well cause markets to start pricing in a dovish pivot by the BoJ.
Exhibit 3: Japan industrial production and real
Source: BoJ, Cabinet office, Morgan Stanley Research; Note: The dotted line shows the METI's adjusted estimate for the current month.
Exhibit 4: Labor market differential DI versus US unemployment rate
Source: BLS, Conference Board, Morgan Stanley Research

Current pricing points to around 1.7 (25bp) BoJ hikes within the next 12 months, or basically the same as prior to reciprocal tariffs taking effect (see Exhibit 5). We think that this is more likely to be dialed back than ramped up given that we are already starting to see some evidence of trade policy adversely impacting the economy.
Meanwhile, as is only to be expected, markets also continue to pay close attention to developments of potential relevance to supply/demand in the super- long JGB sector.

A number of recent headlines have been supportive for super- long JGBs ahead of this week's "big extension". On the political front, the decision by the ruling Liberal Democratic Party to require party lawmakers and prefectural chapter representatives to put their names to any request for an early leadership election appears to have made market participants increasingly confident in the prospect of Ishiba remaining at the helm.

This should reduce the concern about potential fiscal expansion under new LDP leadership, with the basic expectation seemingly that many lawmakers will be uncomfortable going on the record as "dissenters" given that the government's approval rating has been recovering of late.

Moreover, perhaps more importantly, there has also been speculation that the MoF might be set to reduce its issuance of 15.5- 39y JGBs at liquidity- enhancement auctions, with the Nikkei reporting that the MoF floated two proposals at its most recent meeting with primary dealers: one that would see issuance reduced from JPY 350 billion to JPY 250 billion per offering, and one that would see it dialed right back to zero.

Our simulation analysis suggests that the reduction in market exposure to interest rate risk beyond the 10y sector (from October) is likely to be quite gradual under either scenario (see Exhibit 6) and ultimately insufficient to fully compensate for weaker demand among life insurers and other erstwhile regular buyers.
Exhibit 5: Market-implied pace of BoJ 25bp hikes in the following 12 months
Source: Bloomberg, Morgan Stanley Research
Exhibit 6: 10y DV01 equivalent risk of 10y+ market outstanding (less BoJ holdings) under two scenarios
Source: BoJ, Japan MoF, Bloomberg, Morgan Stanley Research

As we discussed in Enter JGB 10s30s Steepener and Short 30y JGB ASW, August 25, 2025, relative performance across asset classes for August suggests that September demand for domestic bonds among pension funds rebalancing their portfolios will probably be at least somewhat weaker than from June through August (see Exhibit 7).

Moreover, just as they did in the final month of 2H FY2024, life insurers may very well use the last few weeks of 1H FY2025 to simultaneously cut losses on off- the- run super- long JGB holdings and take profits on (recently outperforming) equity positions (see Exhibit 8). We thus think that September auction results are likely to end up depending in significant part on the strength or otherwise of demand from overseas investors.

We see a high likelihood of super- long JGBs underperforming on the curve if BoJ rate hike expectations are indeed dialed back, particularly if risk asset markets end up correcting sharply in the process. We thus suggest staying long 10y JGBs given that they currently look cheap relative both to UST yield levels and to the short- term rates expectation; we also suggest sticking with 10s30s JGB steepeners and 30y JGB ASW shorts in anticipation of super- long JGBs underperforming in a declining rates scenario.
Exhibit 7: Monthly performance of each benchmark index
Source:FTSE,MSCI,Bloomberg,Morgan Stanley Research
Exhibit 8: Monthly net purchase of super long JGBs by life and non-life insurance companies
Source:JSDAMorgan Stanley Research
Trade Idea: Maintain long 10y JGB outright Trade Idea: Maintain JGB 5s10s ASW box flattener Trade Idea: Maintain JGB 10s30s steepener Trade Idea: Maintain short 30y JGB ASW
Below, you will find a list of our current trade ideas, entry levels, entry dates, rationales,and risks.
Exhibit 9: Trade ideas: Valuation methodology and risks

Interest Rate StrategyTRADEENTRYLEVELENTRYDATERATIONALERISKSJGB 10s30s steeperer152bp8/25/2025We expect 30y JGB to lag in the event of a risk-offmove due to pension funds rebalancing frombonds to equity, while the less than 10y sectorwould be supported by banking demand.The main risk to this trade is perhaps that of the curve facing further bear-flattening pressure due to upside surprises in US labor market data, arebound in risk assets, and increased expectations of the Fed turning more hawkish.Short 30y JGB ASW60.18/25/202530y JGB ASW currently looks rich, and we expectpension funds rebalancing to shift from bonds toequity should equity start to underperform in theevent of risk-off move.The main risk to this trade is perhaps that of cash bonds continuing to outperform swaps due to demand from pension funds and/or tactical investors focusing on carry.Long 10y JGB outright1.55%8/1/2025With the limited room for lower terminal ratepricing, we see any duration rally on the back of theweak US NFP print to be expressed as a lower-termpremium on the longer-end of the curve.The risk is improving risk sentiment or hawkish BoJ communication.JGB 5s10s ASW boxflattener5bp6/15/2025We see 10y JGB ASW approaching the GC-TONAspread, while 5y JGB ASW still has room tounderperform towards the GC-TONA spread amiduncertainty around the 'substantial' size of QT.10y JGB ASW continues to underperform, led by the cheapness in long-end JGB ASW.Short-Duration StrategyTRADEENTRYLEVELENTRYDATERATIONALERISKSPay SOFR/TONA 1y1ybasis-42.75bp5/30/2025Short-term SOFR/TONA basis is stable even afterthe market volatility in April. Unless demand forUSD increases substantially, we expect the sectorto stay at stable levels. The position providesfavorable carry.The short-term SOFR/TONA basis could widen significantly if the global economy enters a recession and demand for USD increases.
Source: Morgan Stanley Research

Overweight (O). The stock's total return is expected to exceed the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk-adjusted basis, over the next
The next 12- 18 months.

Not- Rated (NR). Currently the analyst does not have adequate conviction about the stock's total return relative to the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk- adjusted basis, over the next 12- 18 months.

Underweight (U). The stock's total return is expected to be below the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk- adjusted basis, over the next 12- 18 months.
Unless otherwise specified, the time frame for price targets included in Morgan Stanley Research is 12 to 18 months.
Attractive (A): The analyst expects the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12- 18 months to be attractive vs. the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below.

In- Line (I): The analyst expects the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12- 18 months to be in line with the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below. Cautious (C): The analyst views the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12- 18 months with caution vs. the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below. Benchmarks for each region are as follows: North America - S&P 500; Latin America - relevant MSCI country index or MSCI Latin America Index; Europe - MSCI Europe; Japan - TOPIX; Asia - relevant MSCI country index or MSCI sub- regional index or MSCI AC Asia Pacific ex Japan Index.
